meanings.sent1: The sick child started to disgorge after eating too much candy.
meanings.sent2: The volcano began to disgorge hot lava, causing panic in the village.
meanings.sent3: The overflowing trash can seemed to disgorge its contents in protest.
meanings.sent4: The burst pipe seemed to disgorge water endlessly, flooding the basement.
meanings.sent5: The overflowing river disgorge its muddy waters into the calm lake.

meanings.sent1: The factory disgorge smoke into the sky, polluting the air.
meanings.sent2: The pressure built up in the container until it had to disgorge its contents.
meanings.sent3: The magician's hat seemed to disgorge an endless stream of colorful scarves.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds disgorge rain, drenching the parched earth.
meanings.sent5: The crowded train station disgorge passengers onto the platform.

meanings.definition: To surrender or yield something unwillingly
meanings.sent1: The defeated army had to disgorge their weapons as a sign of surrender.
meanings.sent2: The corrupt official was forced to disgorge the ill-gotten gains.
meanings.sent3: The stubborn child had to disgorge the stolen cookie after being caught.
meanings.sent4: The company had to disgorge its profits due to a legal settlement.
meanings.sent5: The criminal had to disgorge the stolen jewels before being apprehended.
